contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the heavens and earth as if they were a piece of clothing that will get old and eventually become useless. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: wear out like a piece of clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the heavens and earth as if they were a robe or another kind of outer garment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: roll them up like a cloak

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of the heavens and earth as if they were clothing that could be exchanged for other clothing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they will be changed like a piece of clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means Abraham had very many descendants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: descendants as many as the stars in the sky and as countless as sand by the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses is spoken of as if he saw God, who is invisible. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quote: φοβηθεὶς τὸν ἀόρατον ὡς ὁρῶν ἐκαρτέρησεν
contextId.glQuote: he endured as if he were seeing the one who is invisible

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares God disciplining his people to a father disciplining his sons. You can state clearly the understood information. Alternate translation: "God deals with you the same way a father deals with his sons" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: God deals with you as with sons
